{{cpp/types/numeric_limits/title|infinity}}
{{cpp/types/numeric_limits/navbar}}
{{dcl begin}}
{{dcl rev multi|until1=c++11
|dcl1=
static T infinity() throw();
|dcl2=
static constexpr T infinity() noexcept;
}}
{{dcl end}}

Returns the special value "positive infinity", as represented by the floating-point type {{tt|T}}. Only meaningful if {{c|1=std::numeric_limits&lt;T&gt;::has_infinity == true}}. In IEEE 754, the most common binary representation of floating-point numbers, the positive infinity is the value with all bits of the exponent set and all bits of the fraction cleared.

===Example===
{{example
|
|code=
#include &lt;iostream&gt;
#include &lt;limits&gt;

int main()
{
    double max = std::numeric_limits&lt;double&gt;::max();
    double inf = std::numeric_limits&lt;double&gt;::infinity();
    
    if (inf &gt; max)
        std::cout &lt;&lt; inf &lt;&lt; " is greater than " &lt;&lt; max &lt;&lt; '\n';
}
|output=
inf is greater than 1.79769e+308
}}
